nodes.title: Fortnite
nodes.short_description: Epic's flagship game driving revenue, platform negotiations, and legal disputes.

nodes.title: Google
nodes.short_description: Controls Android and Play Store policies; target of Epic antitrust case shaping distribution and billing.

nodes.title: Unreal Engine
nodes.short_description: Epic's engine powering many games; licensing, ecosystem partnerships, and platform access are critical.

nodes.title: Epic Games Store
nodes.short_description: Epic's PC storefront; exclusivity deals, revenue split, and user acquisition strategy shape competition with Steam.

nodes.title: EU Digital Markets Act (DMA)
nodes.short_description: EU law forcing gatekeepers to allow alternative app stores and billing; expands Epic distribution options.

nodes.title: Tencent
nodes.short_description: Major shareholder and partner; influences strategy, funding, and access to China market.

nodes.title: Valve
nodes.short_description: Owner of Steam; primary competitor to Epic Games Store in PC distribution.

nodes.title: Microsoft
nodes.short_description: Xbox platform holder and partner; distribution, cloud gaming, and cross-play policies influence Epic titles.

nodes.title: Sony Interactive Entertainment
nodes.short_description: PlayStation platform holder and investor; cross-play policies and revenue share affect Fortnite economics.

nodes.title: Epic Games v. Google jury verdict (2023)
nodes.short_description: Jury found Google liable for anticompetitive conduct; remedies may open Android distribution and billing.

nodes.title: United States
nodes.short_description: Primary market and legal venue for Epic's operations, litigation, and regulatory outcomes.

nodes.title: European Union
nodes.short_description: Major region where DMA enforcement enables alternative distribution paths for Epic.

nodes.title: Mobile App Stores
nodes.short_description: Gatekeeper marketplaces on mobile; dictate distribution, billing, and discoverability for Epic products.
